name: wizard-spider

procedures: T1003.002::[Wizard Spider] has acquired credentials from the SAM/SECURITY registry hives.
T1003.003::[Wizard Spider] has gained access to credentials via exported copies of the ntds.dit Active Directory database.
T1016::[Wizard Spider] has used "ipconfig" to identify the network configuration of a victim machine.

T1018::[Wizard Spider] has used networkdll for network discovery and psfin specifically for financial and point of sale indicators. [Wizard Spider] has also used [AdFind] and nltest/dclist to enumerate domain computers, including the domain controller.
T1021.001::[Wizard Spider] has used RDP for lateral movement.
T1021.002::[Wizard Spider] has used SMB to drop Cobalt Strike Beacon on a domain controller for lateral movement.
T1021.006::[Wizard Spider] has used Window Remote Management to move laterally through a victim network.
T1027.010::[Wizard Spider] used Base64 encoding to obfuscate an [Empire] service and PowerShell commands.
T1033::[Wizard Spider] has used "whoami" to identify the local user and their privileges.
T1036.004::[Wizard Spider] has used scheduled tasks to install [TrickBot], using task names to appear legitimate such as WinDotNet, GoogleTask, or Sysnetsf.
T1041::[Wizard Spider] has exfiltrated domain credentials and network enumeration information over command and control (C2) channels.
T1047::[Wizard Spider] has used WMI and LDAP queries for network discovery and to move laterally.
T1048.003::[Wizard Spider] has exfiltrated victim information using FTP.
T1053.005::[Wizard Spider] has used scheduled tasks establish persistence for [TrickBot] and other malware.
T1055.001::[Wizard Spider] has injected malicious DLLs into memory with read, write, and execute permissions.
T1059.001::[Wizard Spider] has used macros to execute PowerShell scripts to download malware on victim's machines.
T1059.003::[Wizard Spider] has used cmd.exe to execute commands on a victim's machine.
T1070.004::[Wizard Spider] has used file deletion to remove some modules and configurations from an infected host after use.
T1071.001::[Wizard Spider] has used HTTP for network communications.
T1074::[Wizard Spider] has collected and staged credentials and network enumeration information, using  the networkdll and psfin [TrickBot] modules.
T1078.002::[Wizard Spider] has used administrative accounts, including Domain Admin, to move laterally within a victim network.
T1078::[Wizard Spider] has used valid credentials for privileged accounts with the goal of accessing domain controllers.
T1082::[Wizard Spider] has used “systeminfo” and similar commands to acquire detailed configuration information of a victim machine.
T1087.002::[Wizard Spider] has identified domain admins through the use of “net group ‘Domain admins’” commands.

T1112::[Wizard Spider] has modified the Registry key HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Control\SecurityProviders\WDigest by setting the UseLogonCredential registry value to 1 in order to force credentials to be stored in clear text in memory.
T1133::[Wizard Spider] has accessed victim networks by using stolen credentials to access the corporate VPN infrastructure.
T1135::[Wizard Spider] has used the “net view” command to locate mapped network shares.
T1204.001::[Wizard Spider] has lured victims into clicking a malicious link delivered through spearphishing.
T1204.002::[Wizard Spider] has lured victims to execute malware with spearphishing attachments containing macros to download either [Emotet], Bokbot, [TrickBot], or [Bazar].
T1210::[Wizard Spider] has exploited or attempted to exploit Zerologon (CVE-2020-1472) and EternalBlue (MS17-010) vulnerabilities.
T1222.001::[Wizard Spider] has used the icacls command to modify access control to backup servers, providing them with full control of all the system folders.
T1489::[Wizard Spider] has used taskkill.exe and net.exe to stop backup, catalog, cloud, and other services prior to network encryption.
T1518.001::[Wizard Spider] has used WMI to identify anti-virus products installed on a victim's machine.
T1543.003::[Wizard Spider] has installed [TrickBot] as a service named ControlServiceA in order to establish persistence.
T1547.001::[Wizard Spider] has established persistence via the Registry key HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run and a shortcut within the startup folder.
T1547.004::[Wizard Spider] has established persistence using Userinit by adding the Registry key HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon.
T1553.002::[Wizard Spider] has used Digicert code-signing certificates for some of its malware.
T1557.001::[Wizard Spider] has used the Invoke-Inveigh PowerShell cmdlets, likely for name service poisoning.
T1558.003::[Wizard Spider] has used Rubeus, MimiKatz Kerberos module, and the Invoke-Kerberoast cmdlet to steal AES hashes.
T1562.001::[Wizard Spider] has shut down or uninstalled security applications on victim systems that might prevent ransomware from executing.

T1566.001::[Wizard Spider] has used spearphishing attachments to deliver Microsoft documents containing macros or PDFs containing malicious links to download either [Emotet], Bokbot, [TrickBot], or [Bazar].
T1566.002::[Wizard Spider] has sent phishing emails containing a link to an actor-controlled Google Drive document or other free online file hosting services.
T1569.002::[Wizard Spider] has used services.exe to execute scripts and executables during lateral movement within a victim network.
T1570::[Wizard Spider] has used stolen credentials to copy tools into the %TEMP% directory of domain controllers.
T1588.002::[Wizard Spider] has obtained and used publicly-available post-exploitation frameworks and tools like Metasploit, [Empire], [Mimikatz].
T1588.003::[Wizard Spider] obtained a code signing certificate signed by Digicert for some of its malware.

description: [Wizard Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0102) is a Russia-based financially motivated threat group originally known for the creation and deployment of [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) since at least 2016. [Wizard Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0102) possesses a diverse arsenal of tools and has conducted ransomware campaigns against a variety of organizations, ranging from major corporations to hospitals.(Citation: CrowdStrike Ryuk January 2019)(Citation: DHS/CISA Ransomware Targeting Healthcare October 2020)(Citation: CrowdStrike Wizard Spider October 2020)
